Revision of Simple Past from Lesson 17

Let's revise some examples from Lesson 17: Simple Past Tense.
He was student – Er war Student.
You had an Audi – Sie hatten Audi.
We could learn German – Wir konnten Deutsch lernen.
I had to play tennis – Ich musste Tennis spielen.

Present, Past, and Past Participle

As discussed in Lesson 17, every language has different vocabulary for past tense – German is no different.
Let's start with 5 verbs and their forms:
InfinitiveSimple PastPast Participle
gehengingengegangen
trinkentrankgetrunken
singensanggesungen
kochenkochtegekocht
spielenspieltegespielt
lernenlerntegelernt

Examples:
Ich kochte Pasta.
Ich spielte Cricket.

Present Perfect Tense

Now let's focus on the Present Perfect tense.
Example in English: I have played cricket.
The verb 'have' is conjugated, and the main verb goes to the end in past participle form.
German examples:
Ich habe Cricket gespielt.
Ich habe Tee getrunken.
Er hat Tee getrunken.
Wir haben Tee getrunken.

More Examples: Simple Past & Present Perfect

He cooked pasta – Er kochte Pasta.
He had cooked pasta – Er hat Pasta gekocht.

Movement Verbs Use 'sein' Instead of 'haben'

When movement verbs are involved, haben changes to sein.
These verbs include: gehen, fahren, können, fliegen.
Example:
I have gone to my father – Ich bin zu meinem Vater gegangen.
Note:

  • habe becomes bin because 'gehen' is a movement verb.
  • mein changes to meinem due to 'zu' requiring dative case.
  • gehen becomes past participle gegangen.

German Tip: Using 'nach' and 'zu'

When Germans talk about going to a city, they use nach, not zu.
Example:
Ich gehe nach Berlin.
If the place is not a city, we use zu.
Example:
Ich gehe zur Schule.
More examples:
I have gone to Mumbai – Ich bin nach Mumbai gegangen.

More Examples of Present Perfect

Here are some more examples using the present perfect tense:
He has gone to Berlin – Er ist nach Berlin gegangen.
I have learnt English – Ich habe Englisch gelernt.
They have sung Macarena – Sie haben Macarena gesungen.
You have played tennis – Du hast Tennis gespielt.

Bonus Tenses in German

Sometimes German gives us some bonus tenses.
1. Simple past and past continuous are the same:
I drink tea / I was drinking tea – Ich trank Tee.

2. Present perfect and present perfect continuous are the same:
I have drunk tea / I have been drinking tea – Ich habe Tee getrunken.

3. Examples with past perfect:
I have eaten pasta – Ich habe Pasta gegessen.
I had eaten pasta – Ich hatte Pasta gegessen.

More examples:
I had drunk tea – Ich hatte Tee getrunken.
You had learnt English – Du hattest Englisch gelernt.
We had gone to Paris – Wir waren nach Paris gegangen.

Note: Look carefully at these examples, as they follow the rules we've learned.

Summary of Perfect Tenses

In this lesson, we:

  • Reviewed simple past examples.
  • Learned about present perfect tense: using haben or sein + past participle.
  • Practiced verbs that use sein due to movement.
  • Discussed how some tenses like continuous forms are the same as simple forms in German.
  • Seen examples of past perfect tense (hatte + past participle).

Keep practicing with these forms to get comfortable with German perfect tenses!
